item.title: My first java :D
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

there’s an alot easier way to do it 

import java.util.*;
public class Test {

	public String ask(String question) {
		Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
		
		System.out.print(question);
		String in = input.nextLine();
		input.close();
		return in;
	}
	
	public void write(String str) {
	
		System.out.println(str);
		
	}

	public static void main(String[] args) {
                new Test.start();
	}

        public void start()
        {
		write("Hej " + ask("vad heter du?"));
        }	
}

Read full topic

item.title: My first java :D
item.dc:creator: @RegeX RegeX
item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

White Castle:

He’s right static is yucky. =)

Meh.
Statics are only yucky in applications that actually support multiple instances, there’s not much point wasting the memory allocation of an entire extra object structure if you’re going to do one thing and destroy anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: My first java :D
item.dc:creator: @Fasga Fasga
item.description:
@Fasga wrote:

import java.util.*;
public class Test {

	/**
	 * @param args
	 * @return 
	 */
	String var1;	
	public void ask(String question) {
		Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
		
		System.out.print(question);
		var1 = input.nextLine();
		input.close();
		
	}
	
	public void write(String str) {
	
		System.out.println(str);
		
	}
	public static void main(String[] args) {
                new Test.start();
	}
        public void start()
        {
		ask("vad heter du?");
		write("Hej "+var1);
        }	
}

Much easier

Read full topic

item.title: My first java :D
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

[code]import java.util.Scanner;

public class Test {

private String var1;

private Test() {

	ask("vad heter du?");
	write("Hej "+var1);
}
	
public void ask(String question) {

	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
	
	System.out.print(question);
	var1 = input.nextLine();
	input.close();
}

public void write(String str) {

	System.out.println(str);
	
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
	
	new Test();
}

}[/code]

He’s right static is yucky. =)

Read full topic

item.title: My first java :D
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

First make a text file called manifest.txt:

[code]Main-Class: Test

[/code]

Note: the enter after Main-Class is essential!

Then make a bat file:

@echo off jar cvfm manifest.txt Test.jar *.class pause

And then run the bat file!

item.title: My first java :D
item.dc:creator: @koffe koffe
item.description:
@koffe wrote:

Well i have user Scar for long now but i whanted to learn a other language, so i started to learn Java… This is only my first program(something) So itÂ´s not so good, Plz send feedback and help me become better.THX:D

[code]import java.util.*;
public class Test {

/**
 * @param args
 * @return 
 */
static String var1;	
public static void ask(String question) {
	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
	
	System.out.print(question);
	var1 = input.nextLine();
	input.close();
	
}

public static void write(String str) {

	System.out.println(str);
	
}
public static void main(String[] args) {
	ask("vad heter du?");
	write("Hej "+var1);
	
}

}[/code]
